ci_support_linux_64_.yaml:
channel_sources:
- conda-forge
channel_targets:
- conda-forge main
docker_image:
- quay.io/condaforge/linux-anvil-x86_64:alma9
python_min:
- '3.10'

about.description:
The central idea is to treat a data structure as a "template" and transform it, using another data structure as context, to produce an output data structure.
There are countless libraries to do this with strings, such as mustache. What makes JSON-e unique is that it operates on data structures, not on their textual representation. This allows input to be written in a number of formats (JSON, YAML, etc.) or even generated dynamically. It also means that the output cannot be "invalid", even when including large chunks of contextual data.
JSON-e is also designed to be safe for use on untrusted data. It never uses eval or any other function that might result in arbitrary code execution. It also disallows unbounded iteration, so any JSON-e rendering operation will finish in finite time.
about.summary: A data-structure parameterization system written for embedding context in JSON objects

about.description:
The central idea is to treat a data structure as a "template" and transform it, using another data structure as context, to produce an output data structure.
There are countless libraries to do this with strings, such as mustache. What makes JSON-e unique is that it operates on data structures, not on their textual representation. This allows input to be written in a number of formats (JSON, YAML, etc.) or even generated dynamically. It also means that the output cannot be "invalid", even when including large chunks of contextual data.
JSON-e is also designed to be safe for use on untrusted data. It never uses eval or any other function that might result in arbitrary code execution. It also disallows unbounded iteration, so any JSON-e rendering operation will finish in finite time.
about.summary: A data-structure parameterization system written for embedding context in JSON objects

name: json-e
raw_meta_yaml:
# yaml-language-server: $schema=https://raw.githubusercontent.com/prefix-dev/recipe-format/main/schema.json
schema_version: 1

context:
  version: "4.8.1"
  python_check_max: "3.14"

package:
  name: json-e
  version: ${{ version }}

source:
  - url: https://pypi.org/packages/source/j/json-e/json_e-${{ version }}.tar.gz
    sha256: b734766ff00f8aa0ab1f2ea6d70893564b7caa44d7fb3e53a955fede0f6c7c32
    target_directory: dist
  - url: https://github.com/json-e/json-e/archive/refs/tags/v${{ version }}.tar.gz
    sha256: 8d039f0e28a22c66ace8d479d0f35a51081ff6dd490e665a88a92281c9c770d7
    target_directory: src

build:
  number: 0
  noarch: python
  script:
    - cd dist
    - ${{ PYTHON }} -m pip install . -vv --no-deps --no-build-isolation --disable-pip-version-check

requirements:
  host:
    - pip
    - python ${{ python_min }}.*
    - setuptools
  run:
    - python >=${{ python_min }}

tests:
  - python:
      imports: jsone
      pip_check: true
      python_version:
        - ${{ python_min }}.*
        - ${{ python_check_max }}.*
  - files:
      source:
        - src/py/test/
        - src/specification.yml
    requirements:
      run:
        - coverage
        - freezegun
        - hypothesis
        - pep8
        - pytest
        - python ${{ python_min }}.*
        - python-dateutil
        - pyyaml
    script:
      - cd src/py/test
      - coverage run --source=jsone --branch -m pytest -vv --color=yes --tb=long
      - coverage report --show-missing --skip-covered --fail-under=96

about:
  license: MPL-2.0
  license_file: src/LICENSE
  summary: A data-structure parameterization system written for embedding context in JSON objects
  homepage: https://pypi.org/project/json-e
  documentation: https://json-e.js.org
  repository: https://github.com/json-e/json-e
  description: >
    The central idea is to treat a data structure as a "template" and transform
    it, using another data structure as context, to produce an output data
    structure.

    There are countless libraries to do this with strings, such as mustache.
    What makes JSON-e unique is that it operates on data structures, not on
    their textual representation. This allows input to be written in a number of
    formats (JSON, YAML, etc.) or even generated dynamically. It also means that
    the output cannot be "invalid", even when including large chunks of
    contextual data.

    JSON-e is also designed to be safe for use on untrusted data. It never uses
    eval or any other function that might result in arbitrary code execution. It
    also disallows unbounded iteration, so any JSON-e rendering operation will
    finish in finite time.

extra:
  recipe-maintainers:
    - bollwyvl
